abstract.p: Marc Hurel letter on Steffen N Johnson's June 30 article scores Boy Scouts's exclusion of homosexuals

block.p: Steffen N. Johnson's argument (Op-Ed, June 30) in support of the Supreme Court's ruling in Boy Scouts of America v. Dale -- that all private groups, including gay organizations, should applaud the result because it protects their right to exclude others -- misses a rather obvious and important distinction.

Steffen N. Johnson's argument (Op-Ed, June 30) in support of the Supreme Court's ruling in Boy Scouts of America v. Dale -- that all private groups, including gay organizations, should applaud the result because it protects their right to exclude others -- misses a rather obvious and important distinction.

Non-Jews rarely assert the right to head Jewish groups. The Girl Scouts would probably welcome the support of more, not fewer, men involved in support of their programs. And ''anti-gay'' people never seek to belong to, much less lead, gay groups. But lesbians and gay men often struggle to be a part of, and sometimes lead, mainstream organizations without hiding their identities.

The right to exclude, even among truly private organizations, is a powerful one. That the Boy Scouts can now legally exercise this right on the basis of an immutable characteristic like sexual orientation should concern rather than comfort people and should inform the next round of debate over the extent to which this particular group is worthy of public support.
